newsitem.title: FRANCE: WorldSpace to announce radio deals June 10.
newsitem.headline: WorldSpace to announce radio deals June 10.

text.p: WorldSpace Inc, the U.S.-based organisation aiming to launch three satellites to offer digital radio services, said it would announce deals with four Asian manufacturers on June 10.
Noah Samara, founder and chairman of WorldSpace, told Reuters during a visit to Paris that the announcement would be made during the Asia Telecom trade fair in Singapore.
He declined to say which companies had signed to manufacture receivers which include the special Starman chip-set manufactured by SGS-Thomson Microelectronics NV and ITT Intermetall in Germany.
"The companies involved are household names in their sector," he said.
Asked whether companies such as Sony Corp, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co Ltd, Goldstar Video Corp or Daewoo Electronics Co would be among the four, Samara said "they are companies like those".

Samara said the first price of the radios, which will allow for a greater number of channels reaching wider areas, could be some $150 per piece but could quickly come down when production was ramped up to meet demand.
"Even at $250 our plan remains viable," he said.

Samara said that WorldSpace would be cash positive within two years after the launch of the first satellite, Afristar in 1998, and be break-even on EBITDA (earnings before interest tax depreciation and amortisation) within four years.
WorldSpace hopes to reach 4.6 billion listeners with three satellites aimed at Africa, the Caribbean and Asia.
